awd_titl_txt: Soot inception in highly controlled counterflow flames at pressures up to 4MPa
awd_abstract_narration:
The emission of soot from combustion processes is a problem that has been plaguing the world for centuries, with repercussions on health and climate that have been fully appreciated only in recent decades. The formation of soot remains a thorny challenge in combustion research because of difficulties in following the critical growth process steps from fuel to soot nuclei. To understand the chemical pathway to soot, it is necessary to sample the gases in a flame in order to conduct chemical analyses.  However, inserting a probe into the flame creates a perturbation, and its impact on the resulting analyses needs to be understood.  The majority of combustion applications, such as in engines, occur at high pressures, with modern combustion turbines operating in the 2.5-4.0 MPa pressure range. The challenges of understanding soot formation in flames are compounded at high pressures, because the flames become invariably thinner and more sensitive to probe perturbations. This research project aims to understand the chemistry of soot formation in flames at high pressures, by creating controlled laboratory flame environments and using a unique technique to quantify the growth of soot nuclei (i.e., small molecule carbon compounds). These studies will impact our fundamental understanding of the soot process, with potential consequences on the design of practical engines, the reduction of the environmental footprint of combustion, and beneficial effects on air quality, public health and climate. 

In this research project, the flame structure and the evolution from parent molecule to large soot precursors, and eventually carbonaceous soot nanoparticles, will be determined as a function of changes in pressure and peak temperature. Gaseous species and temperature measurements will be complemented by soot measurements by two-color pyrometry, laser light-scattering and laser induced incandescence for the determination of soot volume fraction, size and dispersion index, the latter being indirectly related to soot age and carbon-hydrogen ratio. Both diffusion flames and rich partially premixed flames will be examined. Key novelties include: the determination of species profiles with good spatial resolution even in very thin high-pressure flames; the quantification, through a collaboration with MIT, of key building blocks of soot, namely, aromatic precursors up to 6-ring in size, well beyond the typical range of analytical chemistry instrumentation used in conjunction with microprobe sampling; and an unprecedented level of control of the examined flames, encompassing conditions of constant and/or accurately scaled time-temperature history. The experimental program is supplemented by modeling of the flames with detailed chemical kinetic mechanisms through collaborations with researchers at the University of Aachen (Germany) and the University of Milan (Italy) for the refinement of chemistry mechanisms and soot models on the basis of the experimental database produced from this research project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
One of the thorniest challenges in soot research is following the critical steps in the growth from fuel molecule to soot nuclei. The challenges escalate at the high pressures of practical relevance in combustion applications since the flame become invariably thinner and more sensitive to probe perturbations, which complicates the reconstruction of profiles of relevant variables with adequate spatial resolution. The task of this project was to determine the flame structure and the evolution from parent fuel molecule to large soot precursors and eventually carbonaceous soot nanoparticles as pressure and peak temperature are changed in different combustion systems including diffusio flames and partially premixed flames. Key novelties included: the determination of species profiles with good spatial resolution even in very thin high-pressure flames; the quantification  of key building blocks of soot, namely, aromatic hydrocarbon precursors up to 6-ring in size, well beyond the typical range of analytical chemistry instrumentation used in conjunction with microprobe sampling; and an unprecedented level of control of the examined flames, encompassing conditions of constant and/or accurately scaled time-temperature history. Measurements of gaseous species and temperature were complemented by soot measurements by two-color pyrometry and laser light scattering for the determination of soot volume fraction, particle size and dispersion index, the latter being indirectly related to soot age and C/H ratio. The attached image shows a picture of a typical flame with overlaid profiles of Polyciclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) and soot.

With an ambitious, comprehensive and unprecedented effort, with potentially transformative impact on the environmental footprint of the prevailing energy conversion technology, the project provided the most complete description of the path from parent fuel to soot particle formation to date in diffusion flames and partially premixed ones with the simultaneous characterization of gaseous species and nascent soot particles. The soot inception stage per se contributes little to the total soot loading in flames, but it indirectly affects it by providing sites on which surface growth takes place, which accounts for most of the soot in flames. Solving this problem will impact not only a fundamental understanding of the formation of soot, but potentially also its remediation, with beneficial effects on air quality, public health and climate.

The Principal Investigator and his associates disseminated the results in seminars and at technical meetings both nationally and internationally and in nine peer-reviewed publications [1-9]. The collected dataset with boundary conditions was made available to colleagues in the combustion community for modeling purposes. 

Soot formation is an issue of technical relevance not only for the potential engineering problems that may ensue in the functioning of engines but, most importantly, because of its environmental consequences, air quality and health issues associated with particulate inhalation. Soot emission affects combustion technologies that are responsible for more than 80% of the total energy conversion worldwide, with the dominance of combustion unlikely to subside in the next few decades. Combustion-generated soot particulates pose a significant health risk and are considered the second most significant contributor to radiative forcing in global climate change. Particulate Matter (PM) present in the atmosphere is considered the most hazardous air pollutant in urban areas and combustion is the major source of the smallest fraction of PM. 

References

  1. K. Gleason, F. Carbone, A.J. Sumner, B.D. Drollette, D.L. Plata, A. Gomez, Small Aromatic Hydrocarbons Control the Onset of Soot Nucleation, Combust. Flame. 223 (2021) 398–406.
  2. K. Gleason, F. Carbone, A. Gomez, Spatially resolved measurements of soot and gaseous precursors in ethylene counterflow diffusion flames up to 32atm, Proceedings of the Combustion Institute 38, 2517-2524, 2021
  3. K. Gleason, F. Carbone, A. Gomez, PAHs controlling soot nucleation in 0.101-0.811MPa ethylene counterflow diffusion flames, Combustion and Flame, 227:384-395, 2021.
  4. Gleason, K.; Carbone, F.; Gomez, A. Effect of Equivalence Ratio and Temperature on Soot Formation in Partially Premixed Counterflow Flames. Combust. Flame 2022, 242, 112088.
  5. K. Gleason, A. Gomez, Detailed Study of the Formation of Soot Precursors and Soot in Highly Controlled Ethylene(/Toluene) Counterflow Diffusion Flames, J. Phys. Chem. A. 127 (2023) 276–285.
  6. Carbone, F.; Gleason, K.; Gomez, A. Soot research: Relevance and priorities by mid-century, in: K. Brezinsky (ed.) Combustion Chemistry and the Carbon Neutral Future, Elsevier, 2023, Pages 27-61, https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-323-99213-8.00007-2
  7. Gleason, K.; Gomez, A. An Experimental Study of the Sooting Behavior of a Partially Premixed Flame under Moderately Rich Conditions. Combust. Flame 2023, 252, 112429
  8. K. Gleason, A. Gomez, Soot nucleation in diffusion flames and the role of aromatic hydrocarbons, Combust. Flame 255 (2023) 112899
  9. K. Gleason, A. Gomez, A simple method for the quantitative assessment of soot production rate, Combust. Flame. 258 (2023) 113043.

Modified by: Alessandro Gomez
